question_text: What MRI finding is commonly associated with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH)?

options.A: Enlarged ventricles

5-day postpartum patient presents with right eye ptosis. On examination, the right pupil measures 3 mm in dim light while the left pupil measures 5 mm. What is the most likely cause of the anisocoria observed in this patient?
patient has left eye hypertropia that improves with a head tilt to the left. Where is the lesion located? (Implies Bielschowsky head tilt test for CN IV palsy)
The side of the head tilt is ipsilateral to the affected trochlear nerve
options.B: The side of the head tilt is contralateral to the affected trochlear nerve
options.C: The Bielschowsky head tilt test localizes the lesion to the oculomotor nerve (CN III)
options.D: The Bielschowsky head tilt test is used to diagnose abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy

options.A: 45-year-old man suffers bilateral vertebral artery dissections and multiple brainstem and cerebellar infarctions causing right hemiplegia, dysarthria, and dysphagia. Two years later, he returns complaining of oscillopsia at rest. What is the likely examination finding? (Likely pendular nystagmus)

question_text: In a case of right eye complete vision loss with superior temporal defects in the contralateral eye, what is the localization?

options.A: Anterior chiasm

patient after minor trauma was reading a newspaper and presented with diplopia, worse when the patient looks down and to the left. The outer image came from the right eye. What is the muscle affected?

question_text: In a scenario about right internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), where is the lesion located?

options.A: Right MLF
patient with right relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) and right homonymous hemianopia is evaluated. Where is the lesion?

patient presents with nystagmus at primary gaze, low amplitude, and fast beat to the right. What is the likely localization? (Description potentially ambiguous, but asks for localization based on nystagmus features)
22-year-old male presents with symptoms suggestive of right fourth cranial nerve palsy. What is the most likely cause?

question_text: What is the most common cause of fourth cranial nerve (CN) palsy?

options.A: Congenital

question_text: Susac syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of which of the following?

options.A: Visual loss caused by branch retinal artery occlusions

question_text: Which visual field defect is characterized by loss of vision in the lower quadrant of the visual field?

options.A: Contralateral superior quadrantopia

question_text: The amplitude of the oscillation is larger in the right eye. Which of the following structures is most likely to be abnormal on MRI? (Context likely pendular nystagmus post-stroke from Q3/Q21)

options.A: Left inferior cerebellar peduncle

patient with a headache for 2 months, worsening with standing, has occasional blurring of vision upon leaning forward. On examination, she has bilateral papilledema. The CT scan is unremarkable. How to reach the diagnosis? (Suggests IIH or potentially SIH)
case scenario of a patient with one eye ptosis and normal pupils is presented. What is the most likely cause?

question_text: Most common cause of isolated 4th nerve palsy is:

options.A: Trauma

45-year-old man suffers bilateral vertebral artery dissection leading to brain stem and cerebellar infarctions, causing right hemiplegia and dysphagia. Two years later, he returns complaining of oscillopsia. Examination reveals a 1-Hz pendular oscillation with conjugate vertical and torsional components. The right eye extorts as it falls while the left eye extorts as it rises. The amplitude of the oscillation is larger in the right eye. Which structure is most likely to be abnormal?
Lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
options.B: Lesion in the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)
options.C: Lesion in the dorsal medulla affecting the inferior olivary nucleus
options.D: Lesion in the oculomotor nerve nucleus

question_text: What would suggest central nystagmus rather than peripheral nystagmus?

options.A: Direction-changing nystagmus on lateral gaze
options.C: Nystagmus with a torsional component only
options.D: Presence of vertigo and hearing loss

options.A: case scenario describes a patient with a history of blurry vision and headache. She has acne and is taking vitamin A. Examination shows papilledema, BMI 35, and a normal MRI report. Which of the following is the appropriate management?
Immediate lumbar puncture with CSF drainage and acetazolamide therapy
options.C: Surgical decompression of the optic nerve sheath
options.D: Observation and repeat neuroimaging in 6 months

options.A: clinical feature suggestive of right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) involvement includes impaired right eye adduction with left eye nystagmus on abduction. Where is the lesion located?

question_text: In a case of acute painless vision loss (Non-AION), what is the appropriate treatment?

options.A: No treatment available
